Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor. Yes, my temperature was consistently low throughout my chemotherapy treatment but I believe you need to worry more about it rising too much. It is important to check temperature regularly, which is why TPR rounds are done on hospital wards.  You know your own body so if things just don't feel right and you are worried please don't hesitate to contact your breast cancer nurse to put your mind at rest.  Chemotherapy is not pleasant I know but hang in there. Approximately a year ago I was going through the same thing, I felt terrible and I thought it would never end but of course treatment does eventually finish and the good news is that I feel absolutely fine now.
Posts.Title: Temperature worry

Posts.Content: No 21. "I'm sorry you've got cancer". Hidden meaning: I'm even sorrier, I wanted your OH to do yet another long list of DIY jobs for me but now he'll be fussing over you (for a change).  My private thoughts: "I bet you'll ask him anyway because you've got the cheek of the devil".
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Re 13. "Is that a wig you're wearing?" EEK, no it isn't - this is how my real hair has grown back!!!   Thinks: "I'll forgive you and see the funny side because you were so kind, supportive and  understanding when I really needed it".
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Hi Lorraine My deepest sympathy to you and everyone else going through this. I recall only too well the many horrors I had to contend with and yes I had many tough days just as you describe but take heart because this 'hell' doesn't go on forever (although it seems like it at times). It is about eighteen months since my own treatment finished (surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy) and I feel so fortunate to have been given this life-saving treatment, even if I did curse it at the time. The drugs etcetera worked, I'm fighting fit now and I appreciate every minute of every day, even the cold, wet, windy, muddy ones! Have faith, just hang in there, take things one at a time and you will get through this I promise. You can do it : )
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Ha, Ha, Denzilpants, that response made me giggle!  Here's one for you.  "You're looking a bit pale". Meaning: Hey, every cloud has a silver lining, when I stand next to you now, you'll look like the 'before' pictures of a makeover and I'll look like the really attractive 'after' pictures.  Now just let me find my lipstick, blusher, eye shadow, eye pencil, false eyelashes, false nails, low-cut blouse and hair-streaking kit ............... & !!!!
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: These posts just crack me up. I think someone should collate them, then publish a book on the theme of things not to say to cancer patients and sell it on behalf of MacMillan. The only problem would be deciding on a suitable title. Over to you Denzilpants, Dreamthief and buddies.
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: I think Denzilpants' response "No sh** Sherlock" (succinct and sarcastic) would be an eye-catching title. Mayhap he is a bit of a corrupting influence on us all.....
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: The serious purpose behind the suggestion of a book was that it just might make people stop and think twice before they speak and perhaps raise some much-needed money at the same time. Thoughtless comments, however well-meant, can devastate, which is why so many of us have developed a black sense of humour, out of necessity and as a defence mechanism. I'm a pensioner 'NEDDY' who offers up thanks every day for the life-saving and costly treatment I received.
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: 15. - "Don't worry I'll look after you". The meaning: "Oh bloody hell this is a disaster, I'm not going to be Numero Uno any more. Perhaps I could chuck myself off a small cliff or start blubbering (that usually works like a dream and it will put the focus firmly back onto me again"). Reply under breath: "Stuff you, I'm fed-up with your self-indulgent sob-fests, get lost!
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Ladies, you are not alone. Her (to my OH) "Will you mend my leaking pipe, put up that bit of fencing, and give me a lift to my sister's in your car? My thoughts: I've got cancer, I've only just been discharged from hospital, I'm mutilated, there's a gaping great wound in my chest, I'm in pain and you expect him to be fussing over you? You must be nuts!!!
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: No. 18 "All you need is a lollipop and you could do a great Kojak impression - who loves ya' baby?" Meaning: Doesn't she look odd now she's bald. She looks like she's going to cry. Quick I'd better say something. to make her laugh.  And what was 'baldy' thinking - much, much too rude to print it on this website!!!!!
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: "No arguments, I'm going to come to your house and do your ironing!" Translation: a) Your place is nice and warm (so I can turn my own heating off to save money) b) I'll iron real slow (no worries, it's your electricity I'll be using) and linger for ages c) I'll get offered a nice cup of coffee (maybe two) and biscuits d) I can chat-up your husband (who'll think I'm a ministering angel) My thoughts: Over my dead body! I've got your number and it's not 118 118!
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Hi Helen This must be so hard for you too, especially all the waiting but I think Misty Moley is right, in the end you have to let your Mum decide for herself. I don't feel qualified to give advice about mastectomy choices because I had a WLE but I do have a daughter and what I suspect is that your Mum may be secretly fretting about what effect all this is having on you too, although she will no doubt keep such thoughts to herself. It must be a great comfort to her to have a good daughter like you and be assured that you are doing all that you possibly can in the circumstances. Just stay strong and support her in whatever decision she decides to make.
Posts.Title: Never posted before - Mum has TNBC advice needed pls asap

Posts.Content: So I'm not the only one who had their feathers ruffled by this! It was obviously meant to be reassuring  but glibly stating that it was "doable" was misleading and gave the impression that being treated for breast cancer is just a walk in the park. Most of us had no option but to "do" the operation and not everyone can spring back to normal in a flash. I would not wish any harm to Victoria but if she is unlucky and has to undergo chemotherapy and radiotherapy herself at some time in the future perhaps then she will begin to understand that treatment is not easy-peasy, it is in fact very hard indeed.
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Hi jojomomo I just want you to know that your post rang a bell with me because I can remember feeling really depressed and at the end of my tether one day, bursting into tears of frustration and saying those same words myself - "when will this thing ever end?" I really sympathise because treatment knocks you for six, it seems to go on for ever and ever and it is SO exhausting. It is a real battle but have faith and you will get through it eventually.
Posts.Title: Feels Neverending....

Posts.Content: Right Debbie, confession time.  I used to be an introvert (at least that is how I saw myself) but since my cancer treatment I seem to have morphed into an extrovert. A couple of days ago we went to a country show and there were some women selling hula-hoops. They said "Would anybody like a go?" Nobody made a move except me. "Yay" I shouted and before the husband could stop me I dashed forward, grabbed the hula hoop and started twirling like crazy. Oh I was having fun. A lot of people watching grinned and clapped - they would have been amazed if they had known that I am recovering from cancer. I wanted to jump on the go-carts too and have a race around the track, something the old me would NEVER have done before, but he who is very occasionally obeyed felt that I had embarrassed him enough for one day. If someone had told me a few months ago that I could feel this good I wouldn't have believed them. My husband was grumbling yesterday, he said "huh, I wish I had your energy".
Posts.Title: No amount of preparation can ready you for this emotional journey

Posts.Content: I agree with everything that Crystaljuju has said. I am now approaching my first annual check-up. I lost all my hair and was completely bald, which was rather embarrassing, but it has grown back even thicker than it was before. The chemotherapy was the most difficult part of the treatment but I found the emotional changes were the biggest surprise. You will come out of this experience a stronger person but you may find that your personality has changed, perhaps for the better!  I am much more assertive now, I am extremely truthful and I no longer bottle up my feelings. I can tell you honestly that nowadays I feel fitter and healthier than I have felt for years.
Posts.Title: No amount of preparation can ready you for this emotional journey

Posts.Content: Hi CK A diagnosis of cancer is such a big shock, as we can all testify. But take heart because there is HOPE!  These are FACTS - my diagnosis was also Grade 2 invasive, I had to have milk ducts and lymph glands removed, then chemo and rads. Well guess what? Although it was a tough year, it is now approximately 18 months since my treatment finished, I'm still here, very, very much alive and kicking I assure you and feeling absolutely great - honest! (I didn't lose my nipple and I didn't even lose any feeling in the nipple, even though I was warned that might happen. I repeat, there is HOPE!
Posts.Title: New to the site after being diagnosed with breast cancer a week a...

Posts.Content: Of course your mind is in a whirl at the moment and you are not whining because we all felt frantically worried too, it feels like being hit by a thunderbolt, your imagination runs riot and you immediately think of a worst case scenario. You have made a wise decision by joining this forum because you are never alone on here. Remember that there are more and more of us who have been through what you are about to undergo but here we are, still surviving, living and loving life and feeling really well!  The main reason I post on this forum nowadays is to try to remind and reassure the 'newbys' that there is hope.
Posts.Title: Im scared

Posts.Content: Hi fiddlesticks Bra rage! You are definitely not on your own because I also feel cross about the lack of luscious underwear for ladies like us. I did manage to buy some bright sugar pink bras on a market stall and they cheered me up no end even though they didn't have any lace or frills etcetera. You may have hit upon something here because there is a huge gap in the market. Why on earth do manufacturers seem to assume that women who have had breast cancer no longer care about wearing lovely underwear? And why do they offer mostly beige or white? If anything we need glamorous undies even more to give us confidence. Let's hope that some entrepreneur will cotton on to this soon and give us what we want. If they do they had better brace themselves for the stampede that will surely follow.
Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Kerry Here's my experience. My diagnosis was very similar to yours. I had lumpectomy, chemo then rads. I had 3 FEC and was supposed to have had 3 Docetaxol. Although I never suffered from depression  the chemo made me feel very bad indeed and it got a bit worse with each new session. After 3 FEC then 2 lots of Docetaxol I just thought to myself I've had enough, I can't take any more and so I flatly refused the last lot. My family were upset but the consultant accepted that this was my decision. I won't lie, I felt worried and nervous wondering whether I had made the right choice. It is up to you of course but I would grit your teeth and accept all the chemo they want to give you if you can possibly stand it. However, having said that, it is about 18months since my treatment finished and there was no sign of the cancer when I had my post-treatment mammogram (one year after discharge). I am still here and feeling absolutely fine even though I only had 5 lots of chemo instead of 6.
Posts.Title: Advice / Feedback please on stopping chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Lorraine My hair also grew back "like a brillo pad" at first but I have noticed that it seems to be 'relaxing' and growing straighter now - I'm quite sad because I actually enjoyed having curly hair even though it was a bit more difficult to style! I spoke to a couple of hairdressers who assured me that eventually a person's hair does go back to how it was before the chemotherapy. My hair is a bit thinner now but nevertheless it seems to grow as fast as it did before.
Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: Naturally you are feeling vulnerable right now Di and that is hard to accept but although treatment is a long hard haul just have faith that things will improve eventually. Cancer does put a strain on marriages and husbands worry about whether they are doing and saying the right things but my gut instinct is that you two will be okay and get through this together. If counselling helps and it is what you need right now then just go for it. I have to admit that I developed a very short fuse during my own chemotherapy treatment. Heather is right, cancer does change your perspective on life but in a positive way I think. I have definitely become a stronger individual. I am much more confident, decisive and assertive than I used to be. I don't allow anyone to take advantage of me or disrespect me and I don't suffer fools. I do what I want to do, not what other people expect me to do. I have finally learned the power of that little word "no". Sometimes I hardly recognise the new me!
Posts.Title: Feeling so angry tired and weak

Posts.Content: Hi Maria I think your mum was saying "buck up" in a clumsy way (mistakenly) thinking that it might help - but it doesn't! When I was in labour a nurse said "pull yourself together"! I could have cheerfully murdered her and I felt like replying "what do you think I am, a pair of curtains?!!!!" Some people simply lack the empathy gene I guess and they will never be able to understand unless they get cancer themselves (not that we would wish this on anyone). With others even saying the word cancer frightens them. You have a good husband by the sound of it so I would just keep your distance from the family for a bit because they are obviously making you feel stressed. People convalesce at different rates, some snap back to how they were immediately, others need more time. If you feel upset and frustrated and need to 'let it all out' just keep posting on here and we'll willingly listen. Peace and love.
Posts.Title: Extended family have turned their back on me

Posts.Content: Hi Jo You have identified the problem yourself by saying that you have had "time to think" and your mind is jumping ahead by leaps and bounds. By all means take practical measures to help you to keep calm such as listening to soothing music or doing yoga etcetera but the best advice I can give you is to just take each day as it comes and cross those bridges one at a time. I'm not suggesting that this will be easy but do make a real effort not to dwell upon possible negative outcomes because most of your fears will probably never come to pass. Instead make a point of reading all the positive posts by the many cancer survivors who are doing really well. It is 18 months since I was given the 'all clear', I am a fully fledged "Neddy" (as George calls us) and even the dismal weather cannot dampen my spirits. I'm the one walking around with the big sunny smile on my face because I realise how fortunate I am and how lucky to have been given this treatment, difficult though it was getting through it at the time. Just hang in there and hopefully one day soon you will be feeling the same.
Posts.Title: Feeling anxious....what can i expect?

Posts.Content: Don't give your life to someone else - wise words indeed Mandy. I did many things out of kindness for someone for years and years because they feigned helplessness and vulnerability. However when I became ill with cancer this person reacted angrily when they realised that no more help would be forthcoming because I was putting myself first for a change. I suspect other people are now being hoodwinked by the 'sob story', no doubt with the embellishment that I am the devil incarnate! Be cautious, choose who is worthy of your company, do not just let someone 'choose' you. There are a lots of nice people in the world but also some who are not so nice unfortunately.
Posts.Title: Extended family have turned their back on me

Posts.Content: Bless you, nobody can be all sweetness and light when they are going through all this awful stuff, it is enough to try the patience of a saint and you are certainly not useless. If you feel like a moan, have a moan if that helps. I may have a sunny smile now but believe me I was no Pollyanna, in fact I was an absolute pain in the neck when I was in the middle of my own treatment, it is a wonder the nurses didn't murder me. It was hard at times to believe that it would ever come to an end but of course eventually it did and yes it definitely was worth it so hold tight onto that thought.
Posts.Title: Feeling anxious....what can i expect?

Posts.Content: Hi Pam None of us were that 'strong' at the beginning of treatment and I bet all of us have had our own meltdowns at some stage. My prognosis was 80% and hey, I'm still here and doing just fine.  I used to work in a hospital and I wish I had been given a pound every time a female patient apologetically said "I'm sorry I haven't shaved my legs" because I would be very rich by now! Please don't get in a tizzy about the paper knickers thing because I promise you the nurses won't give a damn about that, they are used to looking after people of all shapes and sizes and they will be far too busy form-filling and checking that they are giving you the correct drugs etcetera.
Posts.Title: Having a meltdown

Posts.Content: Hey ladies - chill! For the record I too am the perfect weight for my size, I exercise regularly and I don't drink or smoke. The old me used to get upset and feel very sensitive about all sorts of things but the one good thing that has come out of having cancer is that I seem to have undergone a complete personality transplant. I genuinely don't give a stuff what "other people" think. Just shrug your shoulders and let them all get on with it.
Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Dear Fiona I am so sorry that you are feeling this way and no, I don't think you are mad at all but you do sound very, very depressed. I am a lot older than you but I refuse to dwell on what 'might' happen, although rest assured I am fully aware of what a tricky little blighter cancer can be. I was also getting pains but I started taking cod liver oil capsules and they have ceased - maybe it is just the placebo effect but who cares if it works. Your body has taken a real battering and it is very tiring being a nurse nowadays. Maybe your aches and pains are simply a result of working so hard at your job. What is "normal"? People react in different ways. The old me has gone, I am a very different person now with a much shorter fuse. My response to this disease has been one of absolute rage and temper. My attitude is "damn you cancer, I'm grabbing my life back". Incidentally I also frequently say the 'wrong' word but I simply assume it is just an age thing. I really believe that you would benefit from some professional counselling so please don't be shy about reaching out and asking for help because you are only human, just like the rest of us.
Posts.Title: Feeling Morbid

Posts.Content: Hi Majic I think it is impossible to remain exactly the same person afterwards but in some ways that is not a bad thing. I used to feel upset and tearful if someone was verbally abusive or disrespectful or let me down by casually braking promises they had made.. Nowadays I get good and angry.. My sticker would have to read "Don't even think about messing me about - Mrs Soft-Touch has retired - the job vacancy has been filled by Ms Butt-Kicker"!!!!
Posts.Title: Getting back to "normal"

Posts.Content: Hi Bedy But my chemo was vile too! I also had every side-effect going! Food tasted revolting, I went bald, I lost my nails (they are still not back to normal) I felt as weak as a kitten, I lost weight, I had a very frightening episode when I couldn't breathe so I had to call the paramedics out and I even had two weeks in hospital being pumped full of antibiotics. As a result I was extremely nervous about having radiotherapy and I was bracing myself for the worst but it never happened.
Posts.Title: How many people worked through RT? Is it doable ?

Posts.Content: Hello Mistia Welcome to the club! It's okay to 'lose it' in fact it probably helps to release the tension. Everybody cries at the beginning of treatment because it is a huge shock when you are first told. Frustrating though it may be you must accept that you can't be the strong one at the moment. It is time for others to step up and take care of you now - let them. Nothing seems real, does it? Don't apologise for posting on here because this is what it is for. I also wondered "how long does this go on, just how much more can my body take and will it ever end?" Chemo was brutal but it worked. I was given the all-clear some months ago and nowadays I actually feel much better than I did prior to diagnosis. Hold on to that optimism and one day the sun will shine for you again.
Posts.Title: Had a wobbly and almost lost it!

Posts.Content: Yes we are all different it seems. I had a WLE followed by chemotherapy which was horrific. I was then given 15 lots of radiotherapy - and there was absolutely nothing to it (for me at least). No burning, no rashes etcetera.  I just felt a little bit more tired than usual for a couple of weeks, and then that was it, back to normal!
Posts.Title: How many people worked through RT? Is it doable ?

Posts.Content: Hi Grogg I wasn't referring to you when I said it isn't a competition, I was thinking about a certain shop assistant who 'had a pop' at me for daring to mention that I had cancer when a teenage member of her family "had it much worse than me".  Needless to say she lost my custom and I will never shop there again!
Posts.Title: Just thinking

Posts.Content: And I agree with both of you. If there is one thing that makes me cross it is when cancer is turned into a kind of a competition. A diagnosis of cancer is devastating no matter what type you have or what age you are. I don't say to myself "oh dear I have cancer - but never mind, look on the bright side, I'm old!" Cancer strikes indiscriminately and comparisons are unhelpful.
Posts.Title: Just thinking

Posts.Content: It is a normal part of the healing process to feel sad but as time goes on you will feel stronger, both physically and mentally.  It is interesting that you use the phrase "to lick my wounds" and the word "withdraw" because that exactly describes how I felt and indeed still do. After all the stress and turmoil of treatment we need peace and quiet to take stock and reflect. Some people just don't 'get' that and think we are simply being unsociable. Another change I have noticed is that I talk a lot less and keep my thoughts to myself more. For someone to have undergone cancer treatment without changing at all would be quite unusual I think.
Posts.Title: Tearful

Posts.Content: I had it too in my hands and my feet, bad enough to make me either have my legs hanging off the edge of the bed or my feet propped up on a pillow just to keep my soles from touching the mattress because they were so tender that I was unable to sleep otherwise. I couldn't play my piano for a while either because of the discomfort in my fingers. It took quite a long time (months) but the good news is that yes, it did get better eventually and I'm happy to say that my hands and feet are absolutely back to normal now. I was lucky by the way because I had no problems whatsoever with radiotherapy, for me, at least, it was nothing compared to chemo.
Posts.Title: Loss of sensitivity in feet and finger tips.

Posts.Content: Hi Judy Don't let your mother make you feel guilty about not being with her because if she has not one but two close members of your family accompanying her then she is not alone is she? You are not Superwoman and with the best will in the world if you feel "dreadfully tired" then you must do what is right for you at this time. No doubt your mother will continue to moan and complain but let it all go over your head. Chemo made me feel exhausted but also weepy and depressed but I got through it somehow and I'm now a member of the 'Neddy' club. Please don't apologise for 'dumping' on here, if it helps you that can only be a good thing. When you have cancer I'm afraid you have to put yourself first and you are not being selfish, just practical. It's a long haul, no doubt about it but keep your chin up, try to stay positive and treatment will be over eventually.
Posts.Title: Feeling helpless and guilty

Posts.Content: Hi Operahappy, glad to help.  It's very odd but the only thing that hasn't quite gone back to normal for me is my "chemo nose".  My sense of smell is still really acute but I finished chemo way back in 2014. Yesterday I walked into a pound shop and there was an overwhelming smell of plastic but the shop assistant said she couldn't smell it. Later when I was sitting in a café eating lunch this chap kept walking back and forwards in front of me, going for knives, forks, condiments etcetera to accompany his meal and lordy I kept getting great wafts of his stale armpit odour - it was so bad I nearly keeled over and it put me right off my food! Yuk.
Posts.Title: Loss of sensitivity in feet and finger tips.

Posts.Content: If we had the answers already why the heck would we need to consult a professional?!!! I would not hesitate to get checked out if I was worried about something - better safe than sorry. Was it her manner that was rude? You are not on your own. Only this week a friend of mine, a very highly qualified ex-professional person in her own right, was seething because on her visit to an NHS hospital she had been spoken to as though she was a half-wit. So much for dignity and respect. Don't let the new consultant put you off, go and get that scan for your own peace of mind and if she is rude again tell her you will report her to PALS.
Posts.Title: bloody insensitive doctors !!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Helen  I can't make any promises but what I can say is that several people told me horror stories about their own reactions to radiotherapy and I must have a pretty good imagination too because I got myself worked up into a right old state anticipating all sorts of dreadful things. Well guess what - radiotherapy was an absolute walk in the park for me. I had no adverse reaction at all - absolutely none. I was so surprised! (I was however allergic to the high factor sunscreen that I was told to use so I was just careful to keep out of the sun instead). I actually found it so relaxing lying there on the couch, with the radiotherapy machine gently whirring away above me, listening to the soothing background music that I nodded off a few times! Everyone is different you see. Admittedly I felt a little more tired than usual for a few months afterwards but that was all.
Posts.Title: Really struggling

Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor When you go out have a close look at all those people who have luxurious mops of hair because loads of them will be ex-cancer patients who were also bald during their treatment but whose hair has since grown back. I know because I am one of them - my hair is totally mad now! It is only normal to feel vulnerable but if people stare it is often quite benign because a lot of us survivors have a sixth sense and can't help giving a glance of recognition when we see our fellow 'warriors'. On the plus side, Autumn is on the way, the weather is getting cooler and very soon everybody will be wearing woolly hats so nobody will 'twig' that you are a cancer patient because everyone looks the same wearing their gloves, scarves and beanies. I may be weird but sometimes I actually miss my 'number one' hairstyle-as- was. Some people actually prefer to keep their hair very short after treatment because they find they like it. I met a really pretty lady yesterday who had a flattering silver pixie cut and when I complimented her on it she confirmed that she was indeed a member of our 'club'.
Posts.Title: Hair Loss

Posts.Content: Hi Gina I was very impatient for them to get on with my operation once I knew I had to have it.The waiting is  hard I know, you have too much time to think. Once you start treatment you will feel much calmer. As someone else pointed out it is "the fear of the unknown" that is the real bugbear. Why can't you admit to feeling terrified?  Believe me everyone feels like this, you don't have to put on a front and stray strong. Don't bottle things up, let your feelings out, have a cry if you feel like it. The cancer had gone into my lymph nodes but I'm not losing any sleep over it. I exercise regularly, eat healthily and I feel and look really well. One year on from diagnosis I'm laid back and relaxed, just tootling along as before and life has returned to normal. I don't gaze at my breast or cry over my operation scar every day either, I'm much too busy having fun!  If I do happen to glance at it I breathe a sigh of relief and say to myself "aren't I lucky to live in a country where this operation is available and that they were able to get rid of the cancer for me".
Posts.Title: Struggling on the inside
